thread.title: Do these naked women offend you? Gallery visitors demand 'disgusting and obscene' nude photos be taken down
thread.title_full: Do these naked women offend you? Gallery visitors demand 'disgusting and obscene' nude photos be taken down

author: Rachel Bishop
title: Do these naked women offend you? Gallery visitors demand 'disgusting and obscene' nude photos be taken down
text:
News Do these naked women offend you? Gallery visitors demand 'disgusting and obscene' nude photos be taken down The Victorian art was removed from a Valentine's Day exhibition after three outraged women complained they were 'obscene and bordered on pornographic' Share One of the nude photos which was taken down (Photo: Caters) Share Get daily updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
A series of nude photos from the 19th century have been removed from an art gallery after outraged visitors said they were "disgusting and obscene." 
The Victorian art , depicting nude and partially clothed women, received complaints after being put on display as part of a Valentine's Day "Romance" exhibition. 
But the photos were spotted by three women, aged between 60 and 80, who were outraged by the works, describing them as 'obscene and bordered on pornographic.' 
They demanded the six offending photos be withdrawn from The Cube Gallery, within the South Downs Heritage Centre in Hassocks, West Sussex. 
The women had not visited to view the exhibition, but saw the works while walking around the centre's garden centre and cafe. One of the snaps shows a woman exposing her breast (Photo: Caters) The photos were on display as part of a Valentine's Day "Romance" exhibition (Photo: Caters) 
Di Nee, 65, who runs The Cube Gallery with her husband Martin, said: "We had three separate complaints from older ladies. 
They came in and said the photographs were absolutely disgusting. 
"They thought they were obscene and bordered on pornographic but the images are nothing of the sort. 
"There is nudity but I wouldn't even describe them as racy and they certainly aren't pornographic." However, after an overwhelming show of public support, the couple decided to reinstate the pieces - with a warning to visitors. One of the photos that was branded "disgusting and obscene" (Photo: Caters) A full-frontal nude shot (Photo: Caters) 
Di said: "Obviously we didn't want to offend anyone visiting the exhibition so we took them down straight away. 
"However, after consideration by the heritage centre the photos are going to be put back up - though we will put a notice up warning visitors there are photos which contain some nudity at the back of the exhibition." 
Among the black-and-white photographs is a picture of three naked ladies holding hands and dancing. 
Another photo shows a lady wearing stockings and facing away from the camera with a bare bottom while a third shows a naked woman sitting on a plinth. 
Di said it is not known who the photographic works are by and they were donated to the gallery by a local collector. After an overwhelming show of public support, the couple decided to reinstate the pieces - with a warning to visitors (Photo: Caters) 
The photographs were displayed alongside work by local sculptors and artists, as well as works by Sir William Russell Flint and John Yardley. 
Exhibition organiser Martin Nee, said: "The work was given to us by a local art collector. 
"Before 1839, depictions of nudity generally consisted of paintings, drawings and engravings. 
"Artists then began to use new photography techniques and technology as a new and exciting way to depict the nude form. 
"The history of this art form is probably more interesting than the work itself to a lot of people. 
"Obviously, it was not intended to cause offence." 
The free "Romance" exhibition has pulled together photos, paintings and postcards from various collections and is within the South Downs Heritage Centre. Like us on Facebook
